content: >http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yzi-iF3CESw&feature=channel Russia to-day reports on-going opposition protests in Georgia. Events took another turn yesterday with the police shooting one of three wanted ex-military types accused of fomenting the revolt of a tank unit two weeks ago. The supposed 'coup' was put down peacefully by loyal units of the Georgian Army. NATO exercises in Georgia begin next week. President Saakvishili is under criticism for a lack of action in investigating the death of a former prime minister, and his part in the Ossetia War fiasco.

title: Shaakashvili's Troubles Continue

content: Happy Independence Day! To mark the occasion Saakaashvili is 'democratically' letting opposition protestors block Tiblisi streets and occupy a stadium for an 'illegal' demonstration. The traditional Army parade has been cancelled possibly as the army is either under arrest, or letting NATO exercise them. Saakhaashvili says he doesn't want any 'confrontation' between the army and those protestors. Maybe it's because if the Army gets out on the street, he won't be able to get them back in. And Obama's got problems? On the bright side NATO seems to think Georgia will be joining! >>http://in.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idINIndia-39887620090526?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0

content: History's being made in gallant li'l Georgia boys!. >>http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/27/world/europe/27georgia.html?ref=world Prez Saarkaashvili has told the 60 000 dissident demonstrators that he won't be running for office("If nominated I will not stand. If acclaimed I will not serve. You won't have little Saarko to kick around any more.") when his term ends in 4 short years. They'd like him to 'eff off' now. To which end they've occupied the main train station. According to American sources, bonehead that he is, he's the best 'democrat' for the job ("None of them other Georgians talks english fer pete's sakes!"). Think the NATO observers would be impressed by a cavalry charge, or a katyusha stonk on that train station?

content: >http://worldnetdaily.com/index.php?fa=PAGE.view&pageId=99322 Worldnet is citing an article in G2 Daily which claims Obama has frozen arms sales to gallant li'l Georgia. G2 ascribes this to Obama's wanting to appease Russia. Odd for a supposed font of intelligence, G2 ignores on-going opposition party disruptions and a recent attempted 'military coup'? Maybe Obama's intent is less about 'appeasement' and more about securing American weapons from use in a civil disorder or 'going east' in the hands of as rebel army.

content: quote: End Georgia deadlock by vote or talks -- churchEnd Georgia deadlock by vote or talks -- church TBILISI, May 28 (Reuters) - Georgia's influential Orthodox church called on Thursday for snap elections or immediate dialogue to end an "explosive" stalemate between the opposition and President Mikheil Saakashvili. The statement's recognition of elections as a potential way out will give the opposition new heart after seven weeks of street protests demanding Saakashvili resign over his record on democracy and last year's disastrous war with Russia. "The situation in the country is explosive," Orthodox Patriarch Ilia II said in a statement. "The authorities should take efficient steps that envisage holding early elections or the immediate start of negotiations," he added. An opposition threat to block the main highway and the vital railway line, which some protesters blocked briefly on Tuesday night, deepened fears of violent confrontation in the former Soviet republic, a transit route for oil and gas to the West. The patriarch is a hugely influential figure. Some 60,000 protesters rallied on Tuesday at the national football stadium, before marching to the Holy Trinity Cathedral to hear him speak. The patriarch said then that dialogue was needed, asking what Georgia had gained by ousting its first two presidents since independence in 1991. Disappointed, some opposition leaders accused authorities of putting pressure on the patriarch. Critics accuse Saakashvili of monopolising power since the 2003 "Rose Revolution" that swept him to the presidency. The 41-year-old president has come under renewed pressure since last August's five-day war, when Russia crushed a Georgian assault on the breakaway pro-Russian region of South Ossetia. Saakashvili has so far resisted calls to resign, and analysts say he is counting on the opposition splitting. Watched closely by Georgia's Western allies, authorities have so far resisted repeating a 2007 crackdown by police firing tear gas and rubber bullets against the last peaceful demonstrations against the president. But a brief clash between police and protesters in early May, a day after a failed, bloodless mutiny at tank base outside Tbilisi, has raised fears of a wider anti-government rebellion. The turmoil has overshadowed NATO military exercises running through May in Georgia, to the anger of neighbouring Russia. +http://www.reuters.com/article/asiaCrisis/idUSLS699527 "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: quote: The statement's recognition of elections as a potential way out will give the opposition new heart after seven weeks of street protests demanding Saakashvili resign over his record on democracy and last year's disastrous war with Russia. There may be grounds for empeachment. That is if the constitution of Georgia allows it.
